subject: RE: [junit] Test simplicity or correct usage
msgSnippet: Why not have tests for remove that make sure that when an event is generated that listener is no longer notified, this way you are testing functionality and
messageBody:
Why not have tests for remove that make sure that when an event is
generated that listener is no longer notified, this way you are testing
functionality and showing how the api should be used.

Josh

From: abeacock@...

To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [junit] Test simplicity or correct usage


JUnit'ers,

I am writing a piece (in Java) at the moment that uses the Java
Event
Model (Listener receives Event messages from a Source) to
achieve
asynchronous messaging.

I have the usual Source interface methods:

void addSomeKindOfChangeListener(SomeKindOfChangeListener
listener);

void removeSomeKindOfChangeListener(SomeKindOfChangeListener
listener);

So, you pass your SomeKindOfChangeListener object in, it's added
to
the list of listeners, events fire and the listeners are
notified, and
then when you don't want to listen anymore you call the remove()

method and your listener is removed from the list.

In my tests I have quite a few methods (using MockObjects) that
look
like this:

public final void testListeningForAllThings() {
listener.setExpectedEventCount(1);
listener.setExpectedNodeName("");
source.addSomeKindOfChangeListener(listener);

source.somethingChanged("");
listener.verify();

source.removeSomeKindOfChangeListener(listener);
}

As my tearDown() 'null's out the source and listener objects so
that
they get cleaned up, there really is no need for the final line
"source.removeSomeKindOfChangeListener(..."

My question is regarding whether it's best to try to keep the
tests as
simple as possible or to show correct usage. After all, the
remove
method should definitely be used in production code.

What do you all think?

Andy.
